headline: Chaos at Ohio Senate race debate as Republican Josh Mandel shouts at audience member who said he should be 'put out' for calling BLM 'thugs' and calls his Democratic rival 'like AOC only dumber'
author: Elizabeth Elkind
sentences:

'But at the end of the day, what violates my sensibilities over the past year or two in respect to behavior in that regard that you're describing, is organizations like Black Lives Matter that burned down police stations in places like Minneapolis.'

A debate between candidates running for Ohio's open Senate seat descended into chaos on Monday night as Republican Josh Mandel shared a testy exchange with an audience member over his past comments calling Black Lives Matter activists 'thugs.'

Mandel, who previously served as Ohio's state treasurer, is running in a crowded GOP primary up against a number of other high-profile candidates including Hillbilly Elegy author JD Vance and former Ohio Republican Party Chair Jane Timken.

At another point during the debate Mandel took a personal jab at his Democratic opponent when Harper accused him of being backed by 'big insurance companies and big pharma' and championed Medicare-for-all.
Trump himself has yet to weigh in on the race, though he has already waded into Ohio's midterms with an endorsement of his former aide Max Miller in the state's 13th Congressional District.
Finally getting to the question, he asked Mandel whether he considered Donald Trump's supporters who were arrested for storming the Capitol on January 6 last year as 'thugs' as well.
Mandel, who unsuccessfully ran for Senate in 2012 and 2018, faced off against Democrat attorney Morgan Harper in their second debate at City-God Baptist Fellowship in Cleveland.
Roughly 20 minutes into the event Mandel was being grilled about his calling BLM protesters 'thugs' in their first debate when an audience member made a loud noise of agreement.
Mandel dodged the question, instead disputing the moderator's characterization of the rioters as 'insurrectionists' and pivoted to criticizing progressive groups like BLM.
Harper, a former Consumer Financial Protection Bureau adviser, is running in the Democratic primary up against House Rep. Tim Ryan, an early 2020 presidential contender.
Mandel is backed by Trump's controversial former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn, as well as Senators Mike Lee of Utah and Cynthia Lummis of Wyoming.
Voters in the Buckeye State are looking at a crowded race to replace retiring Ohio Republican Senator Rob Portman, whose term ends at the end of the year.
I had young black men put their life in my hands in the United States Marine Corps in two tours in Iraq, so don't stand there and lecture me.'
TImken clinched Portman's endorsement earlier this month, with several other Republicans on Capitol Hill throwing her their support as well.
Speaking over his objections, Mandel confronted the audience member directly: 'You mean like put him out, like, with a, with a bullet?
I do think there were some people who committed crimes and obviously they're working their way through the justice system,' he said.
After hearing that answer I actually think she's like AOC only dumber,' Mandel said as muted gasps could be heard from the audience.
A Republican primary poll published by a local NBC affiliate last week shows Mandel in the lead with 21 percent of the vote.
Businessman Mike Gibbons trails behind with 16.4 percent of support, and Vance at a close third with 14.3 percent.
Don't embarrass me,' he said as the woman muttered under her breath, 'They shouldn't have let him in here.'
Mandel, who had been watching the protesting voter with a smile, jumped back into the fray to address her.
It was a heated hour-long head-to-head during which Mandel also called Harper 'like AOC only dumber.'
Speaking over the moderator's continued objections, he said: 'Let me tell you something ma'am.
'Listen I think the word "insurrection" is completely inaccurate for what happened that day.
Addressing the irate voter, the moderator said, 'Hey, sister, listen to me, don't do that.'

But to bring that white man into the black community like that --'
'-- I'm, I'm finished.
At the end of the debate Harper could be seen declining Mandel's offer for a handshake.
The moderator, who is black, immediately attempted to de-escalate the situation.
Mandel, I'm the moderator over here I'm asking you to pay attention to me.
He pushed ahead, 'Don't stand there and lecture me about race and color.
And ma'am...will you please stop,' the moderator finally broke through.
Tech executive and Democrat activist Traci Johnson is also in the race.
Mandel shot back, 'I thought this was America where we debate freely.'
He then declined the white co-moderator's efforts to intervene.
'Ask him to leave,' the woman in the audience continued.
Put 'em out,' the female voice can be heard saying.
I put my life in the hands of young black guys.

Don't -- this is America, he can be here.

We put our lives in each others hands.

He's calling my parents thugs.
Make him answer the question.'
